qas.question: What is the backbone of a DNA double helix made of?
What base does guanine pair with?
What causes the specificity of base pairing?

answers.text: adenine and thymine align form two hydrogen bonds, whereas cytosine and guanine form three hydrogen bonds

qas.question: Due to the cause of the specificity of base pairing, what must be true of the two strands in a double helix?

answers.text: The two strands in a double helix must therefore be complementary

context: Two chains of DNA twist around each other to form a DNA double helix with the <a0_0>phosphate-sugar<a0_0/> backbone spiralling around the outside, and the bases pointing inwards with <a1_0>adenine<a1_0/> base pairing to thymine and guanine to <a2_0>cytosine<a2_0/>. The specificity of base pairing occurs because <a3_0>adenine and thymine align form two hydrogen bonds, whereas cytosine and guanine form three hydrogen bonds<a3_0/>. <a4_0>The two strands in a double helix must therefore be complementary<a4_0/>, with their sequence of bases matching such that the adenines of one strand are paired with the thymines of the other strand, and so on.:4.1
